docs.lead_paragraph: Will pre-match sexual hijinks give you the edge you need to win at tennis? Or will they distract you from mobilizing the killer instinct essential to victory? That's the earth-shattering question at the heart of ''Wimbledon,'' a likable, formulaic sports movie that follows the miraculous comeback of an insecure 31-year-old British tennis pro, Peter Colt (Paul Bettany) whose career resurrects on the wings of love. In the eight years since Peter placed 11th in the international tennis rankings, he has sunk to 119th. At Wimbledon, where he's playing his last professional matches before taking a job as a tennis instructor at a fancy club, he meets and falls in love with an American tennis pro, Lizzie Bradbury (Kirsten Dunst). A super-competitive athlete, on the fast track to the women's championship, Lizzie appears unstoppable until Paul enters her life. As her defenses start to crumble, her concentration falters and the trajectories of their careers unexpectedly reverse. Paul credits Lizzie with spurring his triumphs, while she bitterly blames him for her fall from grace.
docs.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews movie Wimbledon, directed by Richard Loncraine and starring Kirsten Dunst and Paul Bettany; photo (M)

headline.main: Learning to Win at Love With a Center Court Rally

docs.lead_paragraph: HIS first two years at Long Beach High School, Wes Moran was going straight downhill. ''I was cutting a lot, did no homework,'' he said. He felt his teachers wanted him to learn new stuff daily, but he didn't see the point. People noticed he was skipping class and sneaking outside for a smoke and pegged him as a slacker. Then, in junior year, he decided to attend the Nassau County vocational high school, the Joseph M. Barry Career and Technical Education Center -- better known as Barry Tech -- ''on a trial basis.'' He signed up for refrigeration and air-conditioning.
docs.abstract: Michael Winerip On Education column on benefits of vocational high schools; such schools are undergoing problems because Bush administration is reallocating their funds to help students pass standardized tests mandated by No Child Left Behind Act and, by 2004, plans to end all vocational financing; drawing (M)

headline.main: When a Student Prefers Learning of the Hands-On Variety

docs.lead_paragraph: For five weeks this summer, 340 college graduates have been going through a rite of passage in the Bronx: learning what it means to be a teacher. Young and determined, thrown into the classroom with just a few days' training, they are part of a crash course run by Teach for America, the public service organization, and the Board of Education. The graduates teach school in the morning in teams of three, then take classes in the afternoon.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dennis Keene has been learning some new French words lately. The forklift parked in the center aisle of the church where he is the music director is a "chariot electrique." The hoist above the altar is a "palans electrique."
